ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As my instructor noted, this course should be called "Intro to Music Theory." We covered all the music theory basics. I had never taken music theory before, so although the material was technically pretty basic, I still struggled a good amount with it.
I learned so much about music theory and approaches to understanding music as a whole. I now listen to music with an entirely different perspective from the one I had before I entered the class.

Basic ideas on rhythm and pitches
Intervals
Major and minor scales
Chords (triads and sevenths)
Basic harmonic analysis
Cadences
Modulation
some details on classical performance and forms
Pop music

I learned about the fundamentals of music theory, starting from reading notes and counting basic rhythms to building triads and analyzing harmonic progression. I do play an instrument but I have very little background in music theory, so I came out of this course with so much new knowledge and skills that will help me.
I became very well-versed in basic music theory and have a good understanding of a lot of what goes into music composition and how to analyze music pieces.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: There is a lot of material and the course makes sure that people with no music background will have a solid foundation after the course. The workload is reasonable with a couple of worksheets about the lecture material every week, then some quizzes, a midterm, and final. Weaknesses: The class moves fairly quickly and is cumulative, so you need to fully understand the concepts before being able to understand the next.

I think the seminar format is great because you get to talk about and try out each new skill that youre learning in music theory with a small number of people. I think however that sometimes the course work required more from you than was possible at the time and it was frustrating.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course successfully transitioned to an online format with virtual lectures with shared slides. I think one aspect that was difficult online was inevitably the aural portion of the class. I think a virtual keyboard or software would have been helpful because it was hard at times to hear her piano playing.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, but be prepared to work hard in the beginning to develop a strong foundation for later in the course. The concepts build on each other, so if you don't understand the first few weeks, the later portion will be very hard. Music is sort of mathy, so also be prepared to struggle a bit if you have a very humanities-leaning brain like I do. (It's not hard math, just concepts that don't come intuitively to me.) In addition, music theory is interesting but not super applicable to anything unless you want to major in Music or make your own music, neither of which I plan to do, so the knowledge I gained feels a bit useless. That being said, it was still super interesting, and if I hadn't taken it I would've always wondered what music theory is. So I'm glad I took it and do recommend it to others.
Yes, if you're interested in learning about music. I think this course is best suited to those individuals who have very little experience, however.

Yes, I would recommend this course to other students. Even if you have no background in music, it is worth it to learn about notes, rhythms, harmonic analysis, which allows you to listen to music with a new perspective.

I would definitely recommend this to anyone whos ever been even remotely interested in how music is constructed. Even though the course focused on classical music mostly, I found myself being able to understand the things that were happening in the music that I listen to and that was cool.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Some portions of the class were taught through lecture slides while other parts were seminar style.

MUSI 110 04
